title.narrative: Transforming Atmospheric Authority: Experimental Embodiments in the Favelas of Rio de Janeiro

description.narrative: The aim of the project is to understand how cultural practices that enable collaborative sharing, testing, and transformation of urban affective atmospheres of stress, fear, and anxiety may support women's participation in rights advocacy and community leadership in marginalized urban communities. The research objectives are: - to explore how creative, non-representational research methods can succeed in combating alienation, fostering dignity, generating new forms of community authority, and motivating participation in community cultural and leadership activities; - to identify, recognise, affirm, and amplify creative practices through which women in the favela are already seeking to challenge or transform tense or stressful urban environments, and to find 'room to breathe' within the city's often oppressive atmospheres; - to draw on robust co-designed empirical fieldwork in order to develop a theoretical account of atmospheric authority that highlights the possibilities for generating new forms of experiential, emergent authority in marginalized urban communities; - to leave a legacy of stronger cultural resources, local research capacity, and practical knowledge of ways of increasing women's mobility, dignity, and participation in community cultural and leadership activities.

Working with women living in an informal urban community ('favela') that suffers high levels of stigma, poverty, violence, and human rights abuses, our project explores the role played by favela dwellers in challenging and transforming the sometimes stifling emotional atmospheres of the city. The project explores how embodied, non-representational creative practices can enable distressing experiences to be communicated, shared, and creatively transformed. Developing participatory research methods that aim to foster dignity and tackle feelings of isolation and alienation, we focus on women's encounters with the varied atmospheres of the favela: sometimes tense, stifling, or terrifying; often, simultaneously, full of warmth, security, and humour. Working to recognise, affirm, and amplify creative practices through which women in the community are already seeking to overcome feelings of stress and isolation, our research explores how embodied cultural practices can help women develop new understandings and insights into the issues facing them, and reduce barriers to participation in community leadership and advocacy. Our research practices aim to enable emerging understandings to be articulated, shared, and translated into practices that work to reduce violence and promote dignity and community authority.
